items.title: De Blasio Owes City $475,000 for Bringing Police on Presidential Campaign
items.abstract: New York City’s Conflicts of Interest Board said the former mayor must reimburse the city for police officers’ travel, and pay a record fine.

items.title: A Pier Deal Is Full of Developer Perks, but Is It Good for the City?
items.abstract: Generous incentives will secure a project that keeps New York’s motion picture industry competitive, officials say. Critics call the price too steep.

items.title: Can He Fix ‘Palace of Scaffolding’ in Time for Belgium’s 200th Birthday?
items.abstract: For an architect trying to renovate his beloved but crumbling Palace of Justice in Brussels, once the largest building in the world, the design challenges pale compared with the political ones.

items.title: States Are Silencing the Will of Millions of Voters
items.abstract: Texas is joining dozens of states that have asserted dominance over cities through a practice known as state pre-emption.

items.title: Will a Dollar General Ruin a Rural Crossroads?
items.abstract: A fight over a proposed chain store is also about what “country” means to different people in a small community.
